name: Zaragoza
fun_fact: Fun fact: Zaragoza has TWO cathedrals - the massive Baroque Basilica del Pilar (largest in Spain) AND La Seo with its stunning mix of Romanesque, Gothic, Mud√©jar, and Baroque styles built on the site of an Islamic mosque!

hero_dishes.name: Migas Aragonesas
hero_dishes.description: Hearty dish of fried and chopped breadcrumbs served with homemade chorizo, local grapes, or fried eggs
hero_dishes.origin_story: Traditional Aragonese peasant food, turning stale bread into a filling meal. The breadcrumbs are fried to golden perfection with garlic and paprika, representing the resourcefulness of Aragon's agricultural traditions.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Miguer√≠a (specialty migas restaurant with Iberian tapas), Los Victorinos (small, crowded authentic spot in old town - no seats, extremely good, low prices), Bar El Circo (best tortillas in Aragon)

hero_dishes.name: Ternasco (Roast Lamb)
hero_dishes.description: Tender roasted young lamb, a signature of Aragonese cuisine showcasing the region's pastoral heritage
hero_dishes.origin_story: Aragon's sheep-raising tradition produces exceptional lamb. Ternasco refers specifically to young lamb, roasted simply to highlight the quality of the meat.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Restaurante Palomeque (awarded Best Roast Veal of Aragon 2022, sophisticated bistro), Casa Lac (historic establishment dating to 1825 with elegant 1800s setting)

hero_dishes.name: Borrajas
hero_dishes.description: Borage - a distinctive local vegetable unique to Aragon, often served in stews or as a side dish
hero_dishes.origin_story: This leafy green vegetable is particularly beloved in Aragon and rarely found elsewhere in Spain, representing the region's unique agricultural identity
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Aragonese restaurants and Mercado Central de Zaragoza (main market with fresh local produce)

hero_dishes.name: Tapas in El Tubo
hero_dishes.description: Innovative tapas creations served in the legendary maze of bars in Zaragoza's most iconic culinary quarter
hero_dishes.origin_story: El Tubo district is the heart of Zaragoza's tapas culture. Tapas are served 1-4pm and 8pm-midnight. The evening 'tapeo' is a beloved local tradition.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: El Tubo district - a maze of narrow streets packed with tapas bars. Los Victorinos for duck meat tapas, Bar Cervino for tavern atmosphere and generous servings with local craft beers

signature_drinks.name: Garnacha and Cari√±ena Wines
signature_drinks.description: Robust red wines from Aragon's wine regions, perfect for pairing with hearty Aragonese meals
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: No Zaragoza excursion is complete without sampling these locally made beverages. Aragon's wines - like robust Garnacha and Cari√±ena - are perfect pairings for ternasco and migas.

signature_drinks.name: Local Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: Zaragoza has a growing craft beer scene complementing traditional wine culture
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed at Bar Cervino and other modern tapas bars, paired with generous servings of tapas in a tavern-like atmosphere

food_culture_notes: The 'tapeo' tradition: evening tapas crawl from 8pm-midnight through El Tubo district
Tapas are also served during lunch (1-4pm)
Standing at the bar is the authentic experience - many traditional spots have no seating
Mercado Central de Zaragoza offers fresh meats, cheeses, fruits, vegetables from local producers
Aragonese cuisine is hearty and flavorful, reflecting agricultural traditions
You might encounter 'jota' performances - traditional Aragonese folk dance and song
Food is integral to Zaragoza's cultural identity, blending rustic tradition with modern innovation
